Advanced JavaScript - new

23 Feb 2017

Since I just wrote up a blog post on the this keyword, I figured I would round up some knowledge on new. The new keyword does have some built in ties to this that I want to illuminate, but I also want to clarify some misconceptions about new in the world of JavaScript.

One common misconception in JavaScript is that when we are calling new we are instantiating a new object from some sort of class. Instead, what we are really doing here is constructing a brand new object, then attaching whatever properties our function constructor has. For example:

Notice that the f in foo is lowercase. This is to illustrate the point that even though we typically see function constructors start with a capital letter, that is simply just a convention to let other developers know that the function is meant to be used as a constructor.

So what exactly happened when we called new foo()? Just like the 4 rules of this, new has some rules as well. Can you guess how many rules there are for new? If you said 4, you are correct! Let us run through what happens when we invoke a function with new in front of it.

  1. A brand new object is created (or constructed) out of thin air.
  2. That object is attached to the function’s prototype.
  3. That object is set as the this binding for the function call.
  4. Unless the function has a return value of an alternate object, it implicitly returns this (the newly constructed object)

Just like this, new isn’t some magical class oriented keyword. Understanding the core functions and principles of JavaScript can really open up the language in many ways.

If you like what you read you can check out my previous posts listed in my archive. Or you can check out my github here.
